article-doc.publication: The Wall Street Journal Interactive Edition

p.link: The Supreme Court ruled that "closely held" companies can invoke religious objections to avoid covering contraception in workers' health plans, carving out a piece of the Affordable Care Act.
The high court ruled that certain workers can't be forced to pay dues to a union they don't want to join.
Obama plans to use his authority to bolster border security and consider taking other steps on his own to change immigration policy.
Israel said it found the bodies of three missing teens in the West Bank. Netanyahu said that Hamas was responsible and vowed revenge.
Xi Jinping's anticorruption drive reached into China's military elite as the Communist Party expelled its highest-ranking figure yet.
Ukraine's Poroshenko declared an end to a cease-fire in the nation's east and the beginning of a new attack to "liberate our land."
Iraq's newly elected parliament will take a critical first step Tuesday to forge a new leadership amid the nation's sectarian conflict.
Pakistan's military began a major ground offensive against militants in the North Waziristan tribal area.
New York state's Court of Appeals ruled that municipalities can use zoning laws to prohibit fracking.

article-body.p: Died: Frank Cashen, 88, executive behind championship Mets, Orioles teams.
Finally, one last What's News blurb that has no link and no bold highlight.
